page.title: 10The Holybush Inn, Oldland
page.content: Present premises were erected in 1730 as 2 cottages, now converted and used primarily for sale of alcoholic liquor. Increasing percentage of total income now comes from serving of meals at average cost of Â£3.50 for soup, scampi, chips, peas and salad, gateau with cream and coffee. The premises, carpeted and furnished to a reasonable standard, is very much a local meeting place with the majority of customers in 18-35 years age group. The most popular drink sold is lager at 98p per pint and the most popular spirit is brandy at 77p for 1/6th gill. In summer, meals and drinks are served in a newly completed area outside. The landlord considers his job hard work with long hours but never dull. Regular music and a video are provided in the bar. No overnight accommodation is offered.
